content: Game was fun, but the weapon Mastery NPC never appeared in my save file, despite following every single guide for the original game, mobile port, etc. Killed the joy of finally maxing out the team's job levels.

Final Fantasy III. The final title in the Famicom trilogy and some would say the best one. The game runs way smoother than FFI and FFII on Android and is a great one-to-one port of FFIII DS. Unlike FF1 and FF2, this game features the art gallery and shows you some concept art for the characters and setting for the opening cutscene. Would highly recommend to someone who is looking to play the third entry and missed the DS Version.

This game can best be described as 'Final Fantasy Improved'. The third entry in the series essentially added in a lot of nice things that the original fame did not have - such as a story, the ability to change jobs, and using spells to interact with the environment. The port was perfect and never did I feel the controls holding me back from playing. However, for all the good points of the game, one failing it has is that its story and gameplay were arot of bland and generic. Maybe overpriced.
This is not ff3. Ff3 was on snes not ps1. .... Just mislabeled. But I spent 15 bucks on incorrect label... Correct me if I am wrong and be someone who has played the snes title FF3....
Really, "Bahamur"? Otherwise I really enjoyed the game. I like the class system. Didn't quite reach onion status though.
I bought final fantasy another final fantasy but this one is by far the best final fantasy I paid for and is very fun I enjoy it

Ff3 has been an interesting game for me since i played it on the ds. For fans of FF14, this is the game in which the crystal tower alliance raid comes from as well as some of the story elements of heavensward and shadowbringers.
Most underrated Final Fantasy game. The moving controls can be a little frustrating at times but overall it's the exact same as the DS version
Really Cool great idea for the game and really cool bosses :D

This was as well-done as I could have hoped, for a mobile port of Final Fantasy. The touch controls are totally fine, and easy to get used to, but the app does support using a controller instead, if you want. It has two options for different button configurations if you do. The graphics look pretty good, for what they are. I personally would prefer clean 2D graphics over the blocky 3D ones that it has. But I really enjoyed the game and played it all the way through. Lots of fun.

Ended up hating it. At the start the goblins are fine but after I left the starting town and got a few companions but every monster 1 shot kills the team in the near area. I gave up. Not going to fight goblins for 1 xp while every other creature was hitting my guys for 85 to 120 damage near the start town.

Definitely one of the hardest final fantasy games. The job system here is new and shows it rough beginnings. The job system is nice but the game play undermines the choices. As long as you have a balanced party and do most of the side content you should be okay. A big negative to this game is that it does not have a proper continue unlike FF4 so boss battles have unfair high stakes at times so be prepared. Overall though it's not that bad and has a lot charm just seems hard for a "kids" game

This is one of the few FF I actually finished, and I'm not really good at RPGs so the difficulty is definitely not that high. Story may be basic but still pleasant to follow, graphics are really cute and detailed, UI is clean and uncluttered and I love the old school gameplay. Some seem to struggle with the moving D-pad but it allows you to play with one finger. Move across the screen for directions and tap for actions. And the game is actually fully compatible with Bluetooth controllers.
Graphics? I wish they had this game with the original graphics instead of the modernization or at least had a option to make it old school like it should be
This game is great love the music and the story!

Jobs are interesting as their first introduction but only difference are single commands/magic compared to more developed systems in FF Tactics and X-2

This is my first Final Fantasy game if you don't count Chrono Trigger as one. The game seemed fine until I found out that this was originally released for NES (8 bit version) which gave me new found appreciation for it. Pros : 1. Storyline (quite massive for its time) 2. Soundtrack (especially Crystal Tower) 3. Job system (adds replayability) 4. Huge map to explore 5. Auto battle mode Cons : 1. Boring monster designs given this is a remaster (nitpicking)

This app is quite literally a port of the DS version of Final Fantasy III, which itself was a port of the original Japan-only Nintendo game. As far as ports of ports go, this one is better, with more intuitive touch controls and no useless Mognet "feature". The third installment in the Final Fantasy series is from early in the life of the franchise, which means that both the story and the gameplay are quite rudimentary. The job system is lots of fun, adding a level of strategy and replayability.

Played it only to say that I played all the main series final fantasy games. The story wasn't memorable, and the jobs system is super clunky (FF5 got it right later on). Some fights are really rough because character speed seems random. One turn all your guys go first, then the boss goes last and uses its ultimate ability. Next turn boss goes first and uses its ultimate ability; so you get party wipe. Also whoever made that final dungeon/boss is one evil mf.

It just seems as if the evil entities u deal with in this game simply show up and mess around for absolutely no reasonable/relatable cause. This, & the lack of side quests (perhaps I'm simply imposing an anachronistic standard here), are what kept me from giving it 5 stars.

The only thing I don't like about this one is the lack of tents and saving spots.  It's very frustrating to have to go back to towns to revive yourself while leveling and trying difficult dungeons.    Other than that I've really enjoyed it.  It makes you really think about what jobs you're going to use and which characters you're going to specialize or focus a job on.  The story line falls right in line with the other crystal sagas.  This one has some throw backs to the the original NES FF, such as that mages have a certain number of spells of each level, rather than MPs, and spells are bought, not achieved with levels.  But it has some newer things too, like the Geomancer, and of course the whole concept of a job.

The game is 5-star all the way, but the Android app has major flaws. First, it didn't fill the screen, which is a major issue for those with OLED displays. Extensive use of this game will cause edge burn in. Also, this game crashes constantly. Square doesn't support their games with bug fixing updates. Additionally, the game's menu doesn't properly support gamepads, an issue for Android TV users. The game's opening screen says "touch to start" and in-game events/tutorials tell you where to touch the as opposed to which gamepad input to use. So the gamepad becomes a little bit of trial and error (left bumper to zoom in, FYI). 3 stars for now, 1 more star added each for 16:9 aspect ratio support, and proper gamepad support.

I found a glitch to avoid battles.  here's how to repeat it"  In the second temple (after you get the boat from the pirates) ther's a part where you have to use toad, there's a cutscene. use toad right before the cutscene and have a battle. during the battle press 'back' in your phone to 'close app'. afterwards open up FF3, and you'll be in the same spot.   I used this glitch to escape all the battles in the second tower (except the boss) while grabbing all the loot ;)

Can not play this game if not connected to internet as it needs to authenticate EVERY time it loads.  Do not purchase if you will be trying to kill time on deployment with it.  Being a fan of Final Fantasy in any iteration I was entirely disappointed to find out that I can not play this game if I am not connected to the internet.  I purchased FFIII, FFIV and FFV at the same time.  (They were on sale!) Now I have discovered that if I am inside the skin of my ship (Go Navy) or out to sea I can't play them.  What a waste of my money.  I intend requesting refunds for these games.  If they ever fix this so I only need to authenticate once, the first time I open it, then maybe I will change my mind.  Otherwise I will opt to not purchase any Square Enix title in the future.

The Android version of Final Fantasy III was a blast to play through.  I'm a big fan of the original game, and this one does it justice. The controls are simple and intuitive. The remixed soundtrack is fantastic, although the original is hard to top. It's still a very difficult game, even though the encounters and job system are a bit different from the Famicom version. I really appreciate the challenge of the endgame, it was very rewarding to complete. I highly recommend this to any JRPG fan.

As someone else said, you CAN save on the world map.  And although you're not supposed to be able to save in dungeons, you actually can on the Android version.  Here's how: If you're in the middle of a battle that you're about to lose (this means be ready if you're down to 1 guy), then you can exit the app mid-battle.  When you re-open the app, you will see "Continue Game" on the title screen and it will start you in the dungeon, before that last battle you were about to lose.  This is especially useful for the final boss, since that dungeon takes hours to pass before you battle.

NOTE TO THOSE WHO COMPLAIN ABOUT SAVING SYSTEM: Saving while on map isn't new to FF games, but quicksaves are, which is GOOD!!!  Since I don't have a DS, I haven't been able to play FFIII before. I was really happy to be able to get it on my mobile... even if the price is really expensive!!! (think it's a bit lame from Square since they sold this game and other ones on android as well while they were on other "consoles")However, I won't complain about the price too long, because this game is the best RPG I played on android! I actually have played nearly 4 hours and I don't feel like I am near the end of the game, which is a good point. Job system is great, even if you can get lost at beginning with this (when you are used to materia or equipment/weapons which teach abilities... in reference to FFVII and FFIX). But after couple of hours of gameplay, it becomes easier to understand...Takes low internal memory (for quality of the game). I really like how the touch screen is used! Would really be happy if FFVII and FFIX were available, if possible... Maybe a remake of FFVII would be a great idea since android offers greater possibilities than PSOne (talking about graphics here....)

You can only use a solid "save" when your in the world map. Quick save is for when your in a dungeon/level. You can only load data from a quicksave once, meaning if you load the game from a quicksave, then die, you have to go back to your most recent real "save," done in the menu selected from the world map. So the people complaining they lost all their progress were just too stupid to save while in the world map before they went and fought monsters.

So I've seen a lot of comments on here giving this game a bad review because of stupid reasons like "No quest log" and "Phoenix Downs are too expensive/rare". These people have obviously not played the classic JRPG's. Final Fantasy III (which was not released outside of Japan until the 3D Nintendo DS remake - of wihch this is a direct port) was noted for its difficulty. As were the first 2 Final Fantasy games for that matter.   If you have not played the original Final Fantasies or you have not had experience with JRPGs before the 3D era, you WILL find this extremely difficult. This is from my generation of RPG's where the grind was important and beating the game took hours and hours and made you feel rewarded.   If you are a child of the 80's, pick this up. It's a wonderful title in the FF series. Highly recommended.

Good remakes are hard to come by, and luckily FF3 can add too them. FF3 stays true to its original while having had a complete visual overhaul to stay with the times. Unlike FF1 and 2. Although the story and characters are a bit bland for the standards of today the well balanced gameplay mechanics are still pretty solid. Touchscreen support is also added and works well, though i am still not a big fan of digital joysticks. Ever so often my thumb slides of the side of the screen because of the lack of feedback. But i can't blame this game for that. What i do dislike however is the lack of a decent tutorial. You basicly get thrown right into the adventure, leaving how things work to you. Every once in a while a character might explain something, but for a game where things can go quite deep gameplay wise i rather get a good explanation from the start. So, all in all a good turned based RPG. Nothing really special, just good game out there for android devices, and there aren't many.

All in all, a great game.

This is a great port! But I'm tired of the 1 star reviews from people who don't know the difference between saving and quicksaving.  QUICKSAVING is TEMPORARY, as in, the moment you either load the quicksave, load a new game, or start a new game, it will be ERASED! The game tells you this every time you do it!  SAVING is PERMANENT, but can ONLY be done on the world map! As in, when you're outside of a town/cave/dungeon, open the menu, and you'll notice the SAVE button is no longer grayed out. Hit that button and you can save to one of three permanent save slots.  Also, the game is NOT over after an hour! The game plays the OPENING credits, then the game continues.

It's a quality attempt at an update of a very old game. But it's not without its problems. I got trapped in an area where there was no way to continue - GAME OVER. I recommend keeping several saves at several different intervals of the game to be safe. It is VERY possible to get trapped in an area without any recourse but to go to an earlier save. In my case, I had two saves that both had me trapped on the wrong side of a mountain range with no way to get to the other side. The game created a one way path to an area which seemed completely safe, until you couldn't go back the way you came - or back to your boat or back to anything that would have helped the game to continue.  Also. be aware that this is not the FFIII that you knew from the old Nintento days - it's actually a reskin/remake of an even earlier game - but, everyone knows that by now, right?   Considering the high cost, and being very generous, it can't possibly get a higher mark than 3 stars.
The game is great, but it desperately needs a way to backup and transfer saved games between devices.

My biggest grip is the lack of depth to the story and virtually no character development, something square enix usually nails!

I should have looked into this before I spent $16 on it, but subsequent BUYERS BEWARE: this game does not support the xperia play hardware controls.  In my opinion, this is a major flaw. This is the absolute best game for the xperia controls and the fact that they are not available really makes me feel like a sucker for getting the phone. The touch controls are decent, but are obviously inferior to the alternative of a real controller. This would be an amazing game if they were to make a simple change, but for now the controls are a bit clunky and annoying.  I'm giving only one star because this is really the only recourse we have after having already paid for the game. In truth, they did some good things and I would give a MUCH higher score if the obvious controls were available. I eagerly await a fix.
Translates better than I would have though and not so bad on the battery. To those complaining about saving, you have to be on the world map. Otherwise the quick save is great.

Additionally, half way through the game, you get the airship Invisible.  To not spoil the game, I'll just comment this airship is less intuitive to use and I had look up how to get it to do what it's suppose to do.  Overall:   It was a entertaining, fun, and convenient game to play, but just left me dissatisfied at the end.

If you have already played Final Fantasy 3 on the DS, then you may not want to pick this up (especially because of the price).  If you haven't picked it up on the DS, then you may want to for your phone, they'll be about the same price really.  The touch screen controls are great, with only a slight annoyance during combat.  Sometimes I get a little sloppy and accidentally click my team mates when trying to just tap for "yes".  Besides that, it is a faithful port with great graphics and game play that will take you upwards of 30 hours to beat (if you know what you're doing and don't farm out levels or equipment).  Easily 5 stars.
The controls work great for the phone and the game play is what we have come to expect of square.  Worth the money.

Everything works perfectly. Just make sure to download the game data at the title screen(wrench icon). Definitely 5 stars. A few things I would have loved to see. An option where the last sequence of selected moves of your characters would be repeated with one command and an option to speed up gameplay. Both would help immensely with level grinding. Also an optimize option for equipment. nevertheless, a great port and I would recommend this to anyone who loves this game. Great job android.

When about to lose a battle of any type or when die before it goes to main menu. Hit the home button, go to task manager and close app, and open the game up and click continue, and you will be at the same place where the battle started. (Note,  you must do this while the battle scene is still up, and works with bosses.)

This game works surprisingly well on a touchscreen. I wouldn't have thought that it could work so well, but they managed to come up with an interesting on-screen joystick which works quite well, and everything else is just selecting buttons on screen, so that's straightforward enough. My main complaint would probably be that too many buttons require you to  select them twice, because they use the first selection to indicate that you've selected the button and the second to indicate that you're actually pushing it, which reduces the odds of actually pushing the wrong button, I suppose, but it does make for a lot of extraneous tapping.  WORD OF WARNING: This is the _original_ Final Fantasy III and _not_ Final Fantasy VI (which was originally released in the US as Final Fantasy III), which I was quite disappointed to figure out once I'd bought it, but it's a solid Final Fantasy game nonetheless and definitely worth the money.

I wanted to wait until I fully played and completed the game before I wrote this review.  I played the nintendo DS version so I had an idea of what to expect from the game.  I was a bit skeptical about the price tag but rest assured, it is worth every penny.  In my opinion the game deserves 5 stars in every aspect.  From the sound, graphics to the smooth game play.  Never did the application force close on me ever, and this is after logging in 35 hours of play to beat the entire thing.  The quick save option is so convenient, which allows you to save anywhere at any point in your game.  Depending on what device you are using, I used a samsung note to play this game, the graphics to me was even better than the nintendo ds version.  The touch screen controls takes a bit of getting used to but since I was able to finish the entire game in 35 hrs I realized that there are not many games out there you can play for 35 hours total, so the controls are actually very well done and smooth for any app in general.  If you are thinking about getting this game, don't let the price tag scare you. Once you start playing and getting into the game, your not even thinking about the price.
Great game, perfectly adapted to the touch screen. More FF titles please!

Great to see a ff game but the battle system of this game is incredibly frustrating.  You can't plan combo attacks.  Elements are confusing and un obvious and the lack of status ailment clearing items early on and lack of magic to help clean gets incredibly frustrating at the early stages of the game. A very hardcore old school rpg that is quite unforgiving. Still waiting for FF7/8/9 please square hurry up and port them!
Forget all the pay to play "free" rpgs and play this highly enjoyable classic instead !

This is a truly epic game.  Some of the reviews here are serious misinformation. The game's intro credits start about an hour in to game play. You can 'hard save' from anywhere on the world map,  but can only temporarily 'quick save' in towns and dungeons. Controls epic.  Story epic.  Graphics wildly epic (compared with original). By far, the best 'real' (not casual) game you will find on a mobile device.
Now FFIV and DragonQuest IX please.

Runs great, awesome game. Unfortunately, I can only give 3 stars because it has randomly deleted my game twice. After more than 40 hours in. Both times.   The game data is still present, but it disconnects and won't allow me to play until I can get into town (6 miles) and re-download the game data, which takes a while. Did I mention that the file was never lost? I don't know what the problem is, but if it's not corrected soon you will be getting a nasty-gram from me. I didn't spend $16 on this for nothing.

I've played final fantasy games ever since 1 on the nes but never got my hands on this one until now. The first 90% of the game was addicting retro fun.  However the lack of a true "save anywhere" feature is inexcusable,  especially in the final dungeon. I lost three hours of play time when the final boss killed me.  I won't be grinding through the same 100 random battles and 5 sub bosses just to die again, and pure level grinding lost it's appeal years ago.

The first half of the game ive managed to enjoy with a minimum amount of crashes which has been fantastic. However there are certain things that you have to avoid in order to stop the game from crashing. Like doing things to quickly after loading a game.   During the second half of the game I started to get big problems. When using airships the game will often crash when going near mountains or when landing or taking off or whenever it likes.   Also when loading a game using the continue option you have to be careful if your in a vehicle because it could crash instantly and your trapped.   If anyone from square enix wants me to give them a more detailed reports of situations when it crashes i will be more that greatfull. Final fantasy is my favorite game series. Ive played almost every single one and im a huge fan. If this is how good it can be then so be it, it will surfice, but people who arent such big fans as i am, they will be disappointed and probably wont buy any more of your games on the android platform. Even though i award you 1 star, it is my duty as a customer to inform you that you have not done a good job. This is not a product that describes how gaming should be, i u

I've never played a standalone FF game, only the online FF games. I think you really won't waste your money buying this game. Just play it (no in game buying stuff, which I hate) and after playing about an hour the starting credits are shown and the games actually really begins here. The games is very familiar to me because lots of elements of the game were also used in the online games. I'm talking about the jobs, partying and the music.   I really recommend this game to all people who have ever played a FF game, also to people who have never played one. The only disadvantage I found was the implementation of the battle system, mainly the way  you have to go through some screens which can be boring if you have to fight low level mobs.

I contacted via email 9 days ago. The authentic reply comes today. The customer service is unbelievably inefficient. Alright, the main problem is that unlike traditional game console, it is very likely for a smartphone user to swap his or her phone for a new one within one year or sooner. Thus, it is essential to transfer the save data to the new phone. However, according to the official reply, such simple functionality may not be supported indefinitely. The only way is to root your phone so that you can copy and change the permission of the save data. Truly unacceptable.  Nonetheless, it's a great game and will be forever.

It's got depth, variety, mystery, action, comedy, puzzling situations to figure out, unbelievable graphics, fun exploration, and more great aspects you could ever want from a game! Edit: I started the game a few times while online, and now it works offline. Awesome. Anyway, the game. One thing I immediately liked was that I was actually too weak to stray too far from the first town. Games like Skyrim brag on their level scaling, but I must be one of the few who likes being held back from exploration until I'm more awesome. I get a better sense of progression that way. The story is clich√©d and boring and the characters are one-dimensional cutouts, but that aside, I'm having fun.

First, the bad:  license checks are stupid, there are 100 web pages on how to pirate this game so don't force a network connection on a paying customer like me.  Inability to share saves between multiple devices (e.g. phone and tablet).  Inability to save in dungeons may result in 20-30 wasted minutes if you die.  Pricey.  Graphics can look pixelated on tablet.  Linear story.  All those items are nits though.  This game is retail quality.  I'd rather pay $16 for something this good rather than nothing or a few dollars for a lot of the half-done mobile games out there.  The difference in level of polish is very noticeable.  The touchscreen interface works very well for a game originally designed for a controller.  The jobs system allows the experience to be played through in many different ways.  Tons of content...I am ten hours in and not even halfway through yet.  If you like RPGs bite the bullet and buy this one.  You won't have to buy another game for a while.  (Toshiba Thrive w/ ICS)

Final Fantasy III is a great game, there's no doubt about that. While the touch-screen controls are excellent for the use of multi-touch phones, and the audio turns out to be stellar, there are some problems.  First and foremost the game's looping tracks tend to have a noticeable pause. This really throws off the mood in some cases, especially for sequences that have tracks that are repeated a number of times. (This is very noticeable during story scenes.)  Second, the DS intro that I've come to love is sadly missing. The music in combination with the presentation would have been a great opener, and for a phone like mine that has over 16GB, space isn't exactly a problem.  Third, the phone doesn't want to stay awake. Despite the app supposedly preventing the phone from sleeping, it still fails miserably at doing so.  Other than that the game handles and plays well. A bit steep at $16, but let's face it, with quality titles a price like that is understandable. I just wish that small little bit of polish was presented with it to really turn my opinion of SquareEnix titles on Android to an immediate 180 degree turn.  (Samsung Galaxy S II [SGH-T989] w/ Fresh ICS 4.0.3)

I love the many enhancements such as the Guest NPCs and the overhauled graphics and remastered audio.  My only gripe about the game is the control scheme. I know, I am playing on a tablet, so touch controls are pretty much the defacto scheme. However, I find that the process of moving my PC around the game map can be cumbersome and a tad imprecise (spastic) at times. For example, sometimes I am trying to fly my airship and it constantly thinks I am trying to exit my ship when I am actually trying to guide it in a particular direction. Another example was trying to exit a dungeon/well in a fairly confined area and the control had me constantly re-entering the area purely by accident because the control scheme was directing my PC in the wrong direction.  The only way I see of fixing the controls is to go with a RTS styled control scheme where you basically tap a spot on the screen and the PC moves to that spot. A controller option would be fantastic as well. I have a Gamestop Bluetooth Android controller and would love it if this controller worked with the game. Given that this game was adapted from the NES, I would think reintroducing a traditional control scheme would be easy.

Great port! The controls work very well and are comfortable to use (I really like that the joystick pops up wherever you put your thumb). The game runs smoothly, looks great (better than the DS version?), and I have yet to see it really drain my battery in any significant way.  Saving is fast and the quicksave feature makes playing on the go pretty easy. I hesitated at the price, initially, considering I already have this remake for the DS. But it's well worth it for the time and effort they put into making a great port to Android, plus having it on my phone is way more convenient than having to carry around a DS.

This is an incredible game and impressive port. FF3 featured one of the best leveling/combat systems of the series, and it is brought to Android faithfully. The 3d graphics come from the DS port, and it's a wonder to see them running on a phone (or in my case, a rooted Kindle). This game is easily 60 hours long, which adds up to $0.26 per hour of top notch JRPG entertainment.   It's also got a nice "quicksave" feature that allows you to make a temporary save without being on the world map so you can play the game on the go. The developers tried to prevent the player from using this to cheat by deleting your quicksave if you load or start a new game. It's understandable, but it makes it hard to share the game with more than one person. It's an odd design choice considering they intentionally give you three seperate save slots.  Finally, the controls are excellent. Wherever you leave your finger a thumpad pops up and remains active until you remove it. This way your thumbs never get in the way. The rest of the game is executed through menus and pop-up buttons. The only annoying thing is that this port retains the "zoom" feature from DS to spot hidden objects.  GET THIS GAME.

I struggled with the thought of spending $16 dollars on a game for my phone. It was a difficult thing for me to do. I am SO glad I did. This IS the best classic RPG on the Android. It doesn't seem like a game made for a phone. I'm sure you gaming enthusiasts know what I mean. Most games on a mobile device feel "watered down". Final Fantasy III does not have that feel at all.   If you've played the original Final Fantasy III, or are a Final Fantasy fan, an RPG fan, or just a person that likes a good game, this is well worth the purchase. The control UI is VERY intuitive. The virtual directional pad is dynamically located wherever you place and slide your thumb. The action button, is wherever you tap.  If you are hesitating to spend $16 on a mobile game, just keep in mind how much you'd pay for an RPG on a console or handheld gaming system. Trust me. It's worth the price.  EDIT--- As others have said, the reviewers beating it in an hour, are incorrect. The credits you see after the hour or so of playing, are the INTRO credits. This means you've completed the epilogue. Which means... "Let the game begin!" Been playing for almost 10 hours now. Still awesome! Buy it. NOW!  :-)

I've always been a fan of the Final Fantasy series and for Square Enix having import this to the Android market was a smart move. Not only just an import, a quality import that utilizes the power of the advanced smartphone Android out there. I highly recommend to getting this whether you're a fan of Square Enix or not due to the fact that this is a pure Japanese quality RPG. Period.

Graphics and performance is great, however there are a few technical issues which will hopefully be straightened out soon. At least on the Galaxy Note, the screen turns off if there's no input (doesn't happen with any other game I own), which can get annoying during cut scenes and battles. Also, the sound sometimes briefly skips and, when quitting the game, the text in the "confirm exit" box sometimes becomes garbled. Other than that, this is an exceptional port of an excellent game!

The price is quite costy, but you get what you pay for. Gameplay is just the same as other FF series. But with added features for smartphones. A must have for all Square-Enix fans. Hope to see more games in the future.

Finally an excellent game for Android other than Sonic. Bit of a steep price but well worth it. As it is made as an Android exclusive, there are a great deal of extras (Extra scenes, etc). Basically, Final Fantasy III-3D Directors Cut.  Plays HD compared to the DS version too. Controls work very well too. None of those static onscreen control pads. Controls start from the point of touch instead. So for people with big fingers like me, this makes things MUCH easier.  I am very pleased with this release.  Too bad about the annoying network check. I understand that SE want to stop piracy, but they shouldn't take this out on the paying end user. Which leaves me to a dilema. 5-Stars for the game, or 4-stars because of this. Well, I guess this game is worth it so I settle with 5 Stars, but it should be something considered by developers.

Can't play without an internet connection? What is my motivation to pay for this when I can probably already pirate a version that doesn't need a constant data connection? When are companies going to learn that forcing people to play their way is not going to net them more customers. It is probably going to lose them customers in the end. Until companies learn that adding things and giving new features is the way to motivate someone to pay money over a pirated version, there will always be people waiting in the shadows ready to give those who are tired of greedy companies free versions of their stuff. And don't get me wrong, I love square enix and I love the final fantasy series. I have bought many of the final fantasy games in multiple different versions for different platforms. What I don't understand is why companies would want to give us less for more money and expect us to not try to work around stupid things like requiring an internet connection to play a game that has no internet functionality whatsoever. If they had included cloud syncing of saved games, I would not even be writing this negative review.

This is the original Final Fantasy III. The North American FF3 was really FF6 in Japan. This is a remastered version of a DS remake of the original game. The controls are great, zero issues playing the game. The price is well worth a game that is at least 30+ hours if not more.

This is the ORIGINAL Final Fantasy III that was previously only available in Japan until it was finally released on the Nintendo DS. The Final Fantasy III that was originally released on the SNES outside Japan is actually Final Fantasy VI according to Japanese chronology. This discrepancy between the Japanese chronology and the US chronology was reconciled with the release of Final Fantasy VII. To the actual review. The touch input is very intuitive. Sound sometimes sputters. Very good in all.

To everyone complaining "This isn't Final Fantasy 3!!!":  It's not. The "Final Fantasy 3" game for SNES release in the USA you're thinking of was actually Final Fantasy 6 in Japan.   This Final Fantasy 3 is actually the Japanese Final Fantasy 3.
